## {#flex-eq data-menu-title="Often times we want flexible equations"}

[Often times we want flexible equations]{.slide-title}

<hr>

Prices are important in economics, but not always available for environmental goods.

<br>

:::{.center-text}
**How do we get prices if we know quantity?**
:::

$$
\require{cancel}
\begin{aligned}
Q&=\frac{(400-P)}{80} &\text{Isolate P in terms of Q} \\
\end{aligned}
$$

## {#flex-eq2 data-menu-title="Often times we want flexible equations"}

[Often times we want flexible equations]{.slide-title}

<hr>

Prices are important in economics, but not always available for environmental goods.

<br>

:::{.center-text}
**How do we get prices if we know quantity?**
:::

$$
\require{cancel}
\begin{aligned}
Q&=\frac{(400-P)}{80} &\text{Isolate P in terms of Q} \\
80Q&=\frac{(400-P)\cancel{80}}{\cancel{80}}  &\text{ Multiply both sides by 80} \\
80Q-400&=\cancel{400}-\cancel{400} -P &\text{ Subtract both sides by 400} \\
-1(80Q-400)&=-P(-1) &\text{Multiply both sides by -1} \\
400-80Q&=P  &\text{Flip terms for simplicity}
\end{aligned}
$$

## {#practice-alge data-menu-title="Easy to make mistakes"}

[It's easy to make mistakes while doing algebra. Practice makes perfect]{.slide-title}

<hr>

Solve all in terms of $x$

$$
3x+2=10x-12
$$

$$
4-3(2x+1)=8-\frac{3x}{2}
$$

$$
3(x+7a)-5=b+2(c-4x)
$$

## {#practice-alge-sol data-menu-title="Solutions"}

[Practice Solutions]{.slide-title}

<hr>

:::columns

:::{.column width=50%}
$$
\small
\begin{aligned}
3x+2&=10x-12 \\
3x+2+12&=10x-12(+12) \\
3x-3x+14&=10x-3x \\
14&=7x \\
x&=2
\end{aligned}
$$
<br>

$$
\small
\begin{aligned}
4-3(2x+1)&=8-\frac{3x}{2}\\
4-3-6x&=8-\frac{3x}{2} \\
1-6x&=8-\frac{3x}{2} \\
2-12x&=16-3x \\
-9x&=14 \\
x&=\frac{-14}{9}\\
\end{aligned}
$$

:::

:::{.column width=50%}
$$
\small
\begin{aligned}
3(x+7a)-5&=b+2(c-4x)\\
3x+21a-5&=b+2c-8x \\
11x+21a-5&=b+2c \\
11x&=5+b+2c-21a\\
x&=\frac{5+b+2c-21a}{11}
\end{aligned}
$$
:::
:::

## {#exponents data-menu-title="Exponents"}

[Exponents make algebra WAY tougher]{.slide-title}

<hr>

$x^n=x*x*x*x... (\text{n-times})$

Many environmental variables follow exponential formulas like decay and growth

You might find yourself trying to solve equations like $x^{\frac{3}{4}}=3x^{\frac{5}{3}}$

Use the same principles of algebra and the properties on the next slide to manipulate

## {#exponents-rule data-menu-title="Exponents Rules"}

[Rules and Properties of Exponents]{.slide-title}

<hr>

$$
\begin{align}
x^0&=1 & x\ne0 \\
x^{-n}&=\frac{1}{x^n} &x\ne0 \\
x^ax^b&=x^{a+b} \\
\frac{x^a}{x^b}&=x^{a-b}\\
(x^a)^b&=x^{ab}\\
(\frac{x}{y})^a&=\frac{x^a}{y^a}\\
(xy)^a&=x^ay^a\\
(\sqrt[n]{x}=a)&\to x=a^n \\
x^\frac{1}{n}&=\sqrt[n]{x}\\
x^\frac{m}{n}&=(x^{\frac{1}{n}})^m=(\sqrt[n]{x})^m
\end{align}
$$

## {#polynomials data-menu-title="Polynomials"}

[Polynomials describe more complex relationships through exponents]{.slide-title}

<hr>

$$
\large
\begin{align}
a_nx^n+a_{n-1}x^{n-1}+...+a_1x+a_0
\end{align}
$$


:::columns

:::{.column width=70%}
For example, polynomials often represent real world data better than a linear function

$$
\begin{aligned}
CV&=b_0+b1\text{ row}+b_2 \text{ column}+ b_3\text{ row}^2\\
&+b_4\text{ column}^2+b_5\text{ row x column} +b_6\text{ elevation}
\end{aligned}
$$

:::

:::{.column width=30%}
[Model used to predict monthly climate patterns in Ireland](https://www.int-res.com/articles/cr1998/10/c010p035.pdf)

:::
:::

## {#fundamental data-menu-title="Fundamental Theorem of Algebra"}

[The Fundamental Theorem of Algebra helps us solve for unknowns]{.slide-title}

<hr>

$$
\large
\begin{align}
a_nx^n+a_{n-1}x^{n-1}+...+a_1x+a_0
\end{align}
$$

:::{.center-text .body-text-xl}
*Fundamental Theorem of Algebra:*
:::

:::{.body-text-xl}
**Every nth degree polynomial has exactly n zeros (solutions)**
:::

::: {.notes}
Often times we look forsolution when equations equal zero
Interesting properties at zero or the difference between two equations
Comes from calculus maximization problems (covered in Day 3)
:::

## {#roots data-menu-title="What do I mean by rots or soultions?"}

[What do I mean by roots or solutions?]{.slide-title}

<hr>
What happens if $x=4$ or $x=-3$ in $(x-4)(x+3)$?

:::{.incremental}
- Try the same thing with $x^2-x-12$

- The only way to get $x^2-x-12$=0 is for x to either be 4 or -3

- 4 and -3 are said to be the roots of the equation
:::

## {#foil data-menu-title="FOIL"}

[(F)irst (O)utside (I)nside (L)ast]{.slide-title}

<hr>

Second degree polynomials can be written as a multiplication of their "roots" aka solutions

We can expand using FOIL!


[**Multiply each term in the adjacent polynomial and add together**]{.seagreen}

$$
\begin{align*}
\text{First}&=x*x & \text{Outside}&=3x & \text{Inside}&=-4x & \text{Last}&=-12 \\
x^2-&x-12=0 & &\text{Add all terms together}
\end{align*}
$$

## {#quad data-menu-title="Quadratic Formula"}

[Quadratic Formula solves 2nd degree polynomials]{.slide-title}

<hr>

**For any second degree polynomial**

$$
ax^2+bx+c=0
$$

**The solution to can be found using the quadratic formula**

$$
x=\frac{-b\pm\sqrt{b^2-4ac}}{2a}
$$

## {#slope-int data-menu-title="Slope-Intercept Form"}

[Slope-Intercept Form]{.slide-title}

<hr>

Easiest model to describe linear relationship between two variables

$$
\huge
\begin{align}
\underbrace{y}_{\text{output}}=\overbrace{m}^{\text{Slope}}\underbrace{x}_{\text{input}}+\overbrace{b}^{\text{y intercept}}
\end{align}
$$

## {#slope-def data-menu-title="Definition of Slope"}

[Slope-Intercept Form]{.slide-title}

<hr>

::::{.columns}
:::{.column width="50%"}


Vertical Change per unit of Horizontal Change

$$
m=\frac{\Delta y}{\Delta x}=\frac{y_2-y_1}{x_2-x_1}
$$

Horizontal Slope: m=0

Vertical Slope: m is undefined

:::

:::{.column width="50%"}

:::{.center-text}
**Rise over Run**

## {#ta-q2 data-menu-title="Team Assesment 2"}

You're team measured the concentrations of pesticides in a lake exposed to agricultural runoff. The intern in charge of finishing the calculations ran off for the weekend leaving you all to finish their work. They left behind the following equation describing the total amount of pesticides in the lake if runoff is stopped from the farm by a new policy incentive reducing pesticides use:

$$
\begin{aligned}
&y=(8-2t)(t+2) \\
&\text{Where } y \text{ is pesticde concentration in ppb} \\
&\text{and } t \text{ is time in years}
\end{aligned}
$$

Work with your team to discuss conceptually how you would solve the following tasks.

1) Write out the intern's work in a more useful equation

2) How long will it take for the pesticide concentration in the lake to reach zero? Since the equation is a polynomial describe why one solution is more applicable than the other.

3) Present your findings (Choose between a graph or table)

4) What is the average change in concentration from year 0 to year 4?

5) Explain to your client why concentrations might behave the way they were modeled.

## {#ta-sol21 data-menu-title="Team Assesment 2 Solutions"}

[Solution 1]{.slide-title}
<hr>

Let's FOIL out the equation so it becomes easier to graph.

$$
\begin{aligned}
y&=(-2t+8)(t+2) \\
y&=\overbrace{-2t^2}^{\text{First}}-\overbrace{4t}^{\text{Outside}}+\overbrace{8t}^{\text{Inside}}+\overbrace{16}^{\text{Last}}\\
y&=-2t^2+4t+16
\end{aligned}
$$

## {#ta-q2-sol2 data-menu-title="Team Assesment 2 Solutions"}

[Solution 2]{.slide-title}
<hr>

::::{.columns}
:::{.column width="50%"}

:::{.center-text}
Use the Quadratic Formula
:::

$$
\begin{aligned}
0&=-2t^2+4t+16 \\
0&=\frac{-4\pm\sqrt{4^2-4(-2)(16)}}{2(-2)}\\
0&=\frac{-4\pm\sqrt{16+128}}{-4} \\
&t=4\text{, } t=-2
\end{aligned}
$$
:::
:::{.column width="50%"}
:::{.center-text}
Use the factors
:::

$$
\begin{aligned}
2t-8=0 \\
t=\frac{8}{2}\\
t=4
\end{aligned}
$$

:::

::::

## {#ta-q2-sol3 data-menu-title="Team Assesment 2 Solutions"}

[Solution 3]{.slide-title}
<hr>

::::{.columns}
:::{.column width="50%"}

```{r, echo=FALSE,out.width="90%",fig.dim=c(5,5)}
t=seq(-2,4)
```
